title: FACT CHECK: Terror attack threat in south Indian states? - Times of India
subtitle: News News: A fax message from Karnataka police chief to her counterparts in few other states is now being shared widely on social media platforms suggesting that
author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
vclaim: A fax message sent by Karnataka police chief DG-IGP Neelimani N Raju to the state police chiefs of Tami Nadu, Kerala, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana , Puducherry, Goa and Maharashtra, informing them of possible terror attacks in major cities in the states, is now being shared widely on WhatsApp.While some are receiving the image of the letter without any particular claim along with it, some are getting a message saying "Please be careful when you go out..." along with the image.Times Fact Check received the same image on WhatsApp from three different readers, eager to know if it’s a hoax or not.Karnataka DG-IGP’s letter informed her counterparts in the above mentioned states of a phone call Bengaluru City Police received from a person who claimed to be a lorry driver by the name of Swamy Sundar Murthy, and who claimed to have ‘information to the effect that’ major cities in these states will be hit by terror attacks.Neelimani N Raju, Karnataka State Police Chief, sending a fax message to Director Generals (DG) of Tami Nadu, Kerala, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Puducherry, Goa and Maharashtra is true, but now, it’s been proved that the call was a hoax.The person who made the call -- lorry driver Swamy Sundar Murthy, an ex-army truck driver -- has been arrested. He had also claimed that there are 19 terrorists in Tamil Nadu’s Ramanathapuram and that the plan is to target trains.A TOI report quoted a Bengaluru Police officer as saying, "He seemed to be under the influence of alcohol and it appeared to be a hoax call."The ‘informant’, however, told the Central Crime Branch officers that he got a 'vision' of terror attack during his meditation, as per a report in the Deccan Herald.News agency ANI quoted Bengaluru Rural SP as saying, "It was a hoax call. The 65-year-old lorry driver, Sundara Murthy, a retired Army personnel, has been arrested for making the call.All the states are, however, on high alert.
